docs.abstract: A combination of disappointing corporate earnings and early signs that inflation could be accelerating pushed stock markets lower.
docs.snippet: A combination of disappointing corporate earnings and early signs that inflation could be accelerating pushed stock markets lower.
docs.lead_paragraph: The stock market is forward-looking. That’s a problem when there’s not much to look forward to.

headline.main: Grumpy Investors Can’t Find Anything to Look Forward To
headline.print_headline: Grumpy Investors Can’t Find Anything to Like About the Market

docs.abstract: In June, the Postal Service will unveil stamps using the 50-year-old technique associated with perfume ads and the John Waters film “Polyester.”
docs.snippet: In June, the Postal Service will unveil stamps using the 50-year-old technique associated with perfume ads and the John Waters film “Polyester.”
docs.lead_paragraph: Remember “scratch and sniff,” the bygone technology behind fragrant children’s stickers and magazine inserts?

headline.main: Scratch and Sniff: The U.S.P.S. Wants You to Smell These Stamps

docs.abstract: Caterpillar set the tone when it warned that tariffs on steel were having an effect on costs, and China’s slowing economy pushed down demand for some 3M products.
docs.snippet: Caterpillar set the tone when it warned that tariffs on steel were having an effect on costs, and China’s slowing economy pushed down demand for some 3M products.
docs.lead_paragraph: Stock investors were whipsawed on Tuesday, as earnings from a pair of industrial firms initially added to concerns about the global economy, but a tumble in oil prices later propped up consumer companies.

headline.main: Stocks Claw Their Way Back From an Early Slide Amid China Worries
headline.print_headline: Markets Claw Their Way Back Amid Global Worries

docs.abstract: Surging demand for critical products has created an immediate need for more workers, forcing some companies to alter normal hiring practices.
docs.snippet: Surging demand for critical products has created an immediate need for more workers, forcing some companies to alter normal hiring practices.
docs.lead_paragraph: The volume of food and paper products passing through a warehouse just outside Los Angeles is up 30 percent from the same time a year ago. Pizza deliveries are surging as people around the country hunker down.

headline.main: Help Wanted: Grocery Stores, Pizza Chains and Amazon Are Hiring

byline.original: By David Gelles and Michael Corkery

docs.abstract: In an echo of 2008, partisan wrangling caused a giant stimulus bill to stumble, even as the market plunged and businesses buckled.
docs.snippet: In an echo of 2008, partisan wrangling caused a giant stimulus bill to stumble, even as the market plunged and businesses buckled.
docs.lead_paragraph: If you couldn’t join us on Friday for our special conference call about the business and policy implications of the coronavirus pandemic, the recording is here. The response was enormous — more than 4,000 of you signed up to participate — so we couldn’t get to all of the questions. What should we cover in future calls? Let us know. (Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.)

headline.main: What Will Fill a $4 Trillion Hole in the Economy?

docs.abstract: It remains unclear if the effort to enlist companies like General Motors, Apple and Hanes constitutes an effective strategy.
docs.snippet: It remains unclear if the effort to enlist companies like General Motors, Apple and Hanes constitutes an effective strategy.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s refusal to invoke the Defense Production Act to commandeer resources for the federal government is based on a bet that he can cajole the nation’s biggest manufacturers and tech firms to come together in a market-driven, if chaotic, consortium that will deliver critical equipment — from masks to ventilators — in time to abate a national crisis.

headline.main: Trump Bets Business Will Answer Call to Fight Virus, but Strategy Bewilders Firms
headline.print_headline: Trump Counts on Private Sector for Supplies

byline.original: By David E. Sanger, Ana Swanson and Maggie Haberman

docs.abstract: As treatment with aligners moves from the adult to the younger market, orthodontists are treating more children without traditional wire braces.
docs.snippet: As treatment with aligners moves from the adult to the younger market, orthodontists are treating more children without traditional wire braces.
docs.lead_paragraph: When Carly Feinstein was in ninth grade, her dentist sent her to an orthodontist.

headline.main: No More Brace Face? Teens Increasingly Use Clear Aligners

docs.abstract: The Tennessee River is one of the most ecologically diverse rivers in the world. It is also one of the most polluted.
docs.snippet: The Tennessee River is one of the most ecologically diverse rivers in the world. It is also one of the most polluted.
docs.lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — From a distance, a river looks less like a feature of the terrain than like a massive, mysterious animal. A river is a sleek, writhing being, and even the verbs we use to describe it evoke animation. A river runs through it. A river climbs its banks. A river empties itself into the sea.

docs.abstract: Four simple ideas to help create a better future.
docs.snippet: Four simple ideas to help create a better future.

docs.abstract: As China grappled with the coronavirus, it kept the masks it made. Now that other nations need them, pressure is rising on Beijing to resume exports.
docs.snippet: As China grappled with the coronavirus, it kept the masks it made. Now that other nations need them, pressure is rising on Beijing to resume exports.
docs.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — As hospitals and governments hunt desperately for respirators and surgical masks to protect doctors and nurses from the coronavirus pandemic, they face a difficult reality: The world depends on China to make them, and the country is only beginning to share.

headline.main: The World Needs Masks. China Makes Them, but Has Been Hoarding Them.
headline.print_headline: China Makes the Masks the World Needs. It Is Just Starting to Share.

byline.original: By Keith Bradsher and Liz Alderman
